page.lettertext:
fol.93r
Belgia
1591. stilo Ro
m
23 Fe
b
To M
r
Bodly
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
S
r
. Bicawse it is convenient yowe showld be acquainted w
th
the Negotiac
o
n of the Deputies of the
States
heare, yowe shall
understand, that after the two principall Deputies
De Luz
&
vanden-
berg
, had delivered their letters unto hir
Ma
tie
,
theie used su
m
longe
rownd
speeches, partlie of thanks for hir succo
rs
, partlie in excuse
for not geving speedie awnsweare to
M
r
Wilkes
and yowe: & after
that made their Complaints in generallitie of the Arrests, w
th
request
of Restitucion, and [.] to reforme the like heareafter./
And in conclusion added an awnsweare from the States to the point
required by yowe for the restraint of navigation into
Spaigne:
To
all w
ch
hir Ma
tie
gave them in wordes, sum particuler reasonable
awnsweares, adding that she would appoint sum of hir
Counsell
to conferre w
th
them: and so w
th
in two or three daies they exhi-
bited in writinge the some of theire speeches, and thereuppon hir
Ma
tie
delivering the same unto mee, commaunded that the L. Admi-
rall my
L. Cobham
, my
L. Buckhurst
and my self showld consider
theareof and conferre w
th
them, and so wee did, heare at my
howse at sondrie times: wheareuppon wee did in the ende for A
full awnsweare: after wee had made hir Ma
tie
acquainted w
th
o
r
doinges, geve them perticuler awnsweares to all the partes of their
Remonstrance, whereof I doe forbeare by this my l
re
to make any
perticuler recitall, bicawse I doe send unto yowe the Copies of
theyr first writinge and Remonstrance, and also of o
r
Awnsweares,
w
ch
are subscribed w
th
o
r
fowre handes, as shall appeare unto yo
u
if theie showld varrie from thes w
ch
I doe send unto yowe./
Whilest theie weare heare theie presented other letters to hir Ma
tie
from the States Generall, by the w
ch
is required that hir Ma
tie
would
increase the nomber of hir Horsebandes, wheareunto hir Ma
tie
cawsed
mee to geve them awnseare, that she thowght it strange that they
would move hir to increase hir Charge, consideringe the excesse and
burden that hir Ma
tie
hitherto hath borne w
th
continuance of hir
charge from the beginninge, wheareas the charge of the States from
the first beginninge hath been continuallie deminished, & never increa-
sed till this daie: a matter of soe great inequalletie as hir Ma
tie
hath cawse to thinke it as reasonable to have hir charges to be
fol.93v
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
deminished as theirs hath been: and yet hir Ma
tie
perceiving that
theie havinge had an intention of late to increase sum part of
theire footemen and horsemen, thowgh not comparable to that was
promised in their part in the beginninge, she wissheth that the same
theire intention, might speedelie be executed; & according to this
my awnsweare delivered to them, hir Ma
tie
would have yowe to
deliver the like to the States theare, if yowe finde that theie looke for
anie awnsweare theareto: and uppon mention to be made for the in-
rease of theire nombers, hir Ma
tie
would have yowe to emploie all
the meanes yowe ca
n
to make sum exploit nowe against the
Duke
of Parmas
preparations to goe into
France,
either to weaken his forc
or to hinder his voiadge for utterlie to divert him yt is thowght
not possible. Thus much towchinge the Deputies negotiation heer./
W
th
the Deputies came divers merchants of
Middleborowgh
and
Flushinge,
and other Townes theare to followe their severall Com-
plaintes for Arrest
made of their Shippes and good
, w
th
Request
for Restituc
o
ns: All w
ch
weare putt into a brief Memoriall, and by
[we] that weare Coun
rs
the same weare committed to
M
r
Awbraie
&
the
Judge of the Admiraltie
, whearein for the greatest part the
marchants have been awnsweared as wee hope to their satisfacc
o
n,
and in vearie trewth such was hir Ma
ties
[minde], and such also was
o
r
labo
rs
, as noe good meanes weare omitted to geve them awn-
sweares and satisfacc
o
n: and for such other perticulers of the same
Complaints, as cowld not be presentlie well awnsweared, theare
is order taken that uppon the proofes of the Complaintes, & the prosecuc
o
n
thereof, theare shall be asmuch done to satisfie them, as by reason
ca
n
be devised. And to the intent yowe maie the better under-
stand what hath been hearein proceeded, I minde to send yowe A
perticuler Kalender of the same Complaint
and the awnsweares: &
thearew
th
also I will send unto yowe a proclamac
o
n published
by hir Ma
tie
, partlie uppon the occasion of thes Complaintes, and
partlie uppon Complaintes made by the Seignories of
Venice
and
Florence,
for repression of such [.]
as
of late have been
fol.94r
Belgia 1591 Feb
r
commited uppon the Seas, by men having au
ct
ie to make
Reprisall of Spaniardes good
: Of w
ch
Procamac
o
n yowe maie
doe well to make the States and
Counsell
theare acquainted, soe
hir Ma
ties
[.] meaninge thearein: And as I tooke the paine
in forminge theareof, soe I will vearie gladlie doe the best in my
poore power, to see the Contents thereof ob
s
rved, for in vearie
trewthe, I have been ernestlie moved w
th
noe little Anger
against o
r
Cuntriemen to see soe notable disorders committed under
collo
r
of Reprisall to committ verie kindes of Piracies: But so
manie persons have interest in the gaine thereof, as I dare
not promise so [due] execuc
o
n as I have desyre./
I am commaunded by the Quenes Ma
tie
to recommend unto yowe very
ernestlie the state of
Ostend,
wheareof hir Ma
tie
seeth that the
States have not such Care, as both humo
r
and necessitie requireth,
and therefore in hir Ma
ties
name yowe must treate both w
th
the
Counsell and
e Generall Estates, that nowe presentlie before
the D. of Parma shall be gon into France, the towne might be
further fortefied w
th
two more Cumpanies: for uppon the occasions
geven to
e Ennemie by the great
s
rvices done by
S
r
Edward
Norris
, and the Garrison theare in spoiling of the Ennemies Cun-
trie to their great detriment: and in taking and overthrowing
two of their best Sconces neare to the towne,
Blankenburgh
&
Odenburgh:
It is knowen that the Duke, and spetiallie
La Motte
whose reputac
o
n is towched by the overthrowe of thos forts, mindeth
to attempt sum thinge before the Dukes goinge into France, by waie
of Revenge, to the danger of that towne: and therefore the States
owght in honno
r
, and for the common Cawse, and spetiallie to the
Cumfort of the Capteine and Garrison of that towne of Ostend,
to yeld unto him the aide of two Bandes presentlie for the
defence of that towne: and after the Dukes forces shall be voided
owt of thos Cuntries, the same maie either be revoked or emploied
to
e offence of
e Ennemie./ Besides this hir Ma
tie
would
have yowe [Procure] that S[r Edward Norris, being Governo
r
of the
Towne for them, and not for hir Ma
tie
might be better enha[bled]
fol.94v
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
by his Enterteinm
t
, than it semeth his is, whearein I praie yowe
deale as ernestlie as yowe ca
n
, for the gentleman as yowe knowe
hath noe [livelood] of his owne, as is of his owne nature liberall of
anie thinge he hath emongest his Soldiers: It is also required by
hir Ma
tie
that the Contribuc
o
ns, and other Revenues that are to be
had theare, might be emploied in the fortefieng of the towne, and
defence of it against the Sea: w
ch
if it maie be done, than the
Band that is Cassed, and whose intertenm
t
is nowe imploied for
defence against the Sea, might be againe resolved, and [continued]
for defence of the towne: w
ch
if it had not been imploied uppon the
defence of the Sea, it is certainelie thowght, the sea had eaten up
the towne by this time: and therefore the emploim
t
of the wages of
that Band, hath been most necessarelie imploied thearein./
Lastlie I am commaunded to recommend unto yo
u
an old suite to be er-
nestlie moved unto the States in hir Ma
ties
name for certaine sommes of
monie dewe to poore victuellers in Flusshinge, by the two Bandes of
Randolphe
and
Wingefeeld,
w
ch
in the
E. of Leicesters
time weare
transferred over to the
s
rvice and charge of the States: The case I
dowbt not but is knowen unto yowe of old, and nowe hir Ma
tie
having been pitifullie sollicited, by certeine Deputies of Flusshing, on
the behalf of som poore widowes, she would have yowe to deale w
th
the States generall to yeld to the Releef of the said widowes. wherein
if yo
u
cannot prevaile to gett the whole that is due unto them, yet
if the States will yeld sum good portion thereof, it maie be summ occa-
sion heareafterwardes to induce the Queene for charitie to releve the
parties w
th
sum other portion. Yowe maie thinke som slacknes in
me that I have not geven yowe sum awnsweare to yo
r
request, w
ch
yowe by yo
r
l
re
s moved mee to make to hir Ma
tie
, for license for yo
r
retorne, whearein I did so deale, as I cawsed hir Ma
tie
to reade yo
r
owne request, wheareunto hir Ma
tie
, seemed favorablie to encline. but to
assent theareunto at this time she alledged such reason as I cowld not my
self impugne, w
ch
was that yo
r
acquaintance was such w
th
hir affaires
theare, as untill she might see what might passe this sommer, considering
thes matters of France, and also howe needefull yt weare to have the
States theare ernestlie sollicited to impeach the Dukes forces intended [.]
from [w ]: And thearefore uppon thes reasons you are to take some pat[ience]
for yo
r
aboade./
fr
o
my howss in westm
r
. 23 fe
b
1590
Yours assuredly. W[illiam Burghley].
I cannot at this time send yowe the Re
gr
of
the Complaintes, but by my next I will./
